[[File:Bundesarchiv Bild 101III-Weill-061-25, Heinrich Himmler in Luxembourg.jpg|300px|thumb|[[Heinrich Himmler]], saluted by a Luxembourgish policeman, during his visit to Luxembourg in September 1940, several months after the invasion.]] The '''involvement of the [[Grand Duchy of Luxembourg]] in [[World War II]]''' began with its invasion by German forces on 10 May 1940 and lasted beyond its liberation by [[Allies (World War II)|Allied forces]] in late 1944 and early 1945.
After surrendering after just a day of fighting, Luxembourg was placed under occupation and was formally annexed into Germany in 1942. During the occupation, the German authorities orchestrated a programme of "Germanisation" of the country, suppressing non-German languages and customs and conscripting Luxembourgers into the ''[[Wehrmacht]]'', which led to extensive resistance, culminating in a [[1942 Luxembourgish general strike|general strike in August 1942]] against conscription. The Germanisation was facilitated by a collaborationist political group, the ''[[Volksdeutsche Bewegung]]'', founded shortly after the occupation. Shortly before the surrender, the government had fled the country along with [[Charlotte, Grand Duchess of Luxembourg|Grand Duchess Charlotte]], eventually arriving in London, where a [[Luxembourgish government-in-exile|Government-in-exile]] was formed. Luxembourgish soldiers also fought in Allied units until liberation.
==Background== The Luxembourgish government had pursued a policy of neutrality since the "[[Luxembourg Crisis]]" of 1867 had highlighted the country's vulnerability.<ref name=GduGD110>{{cite book|last=Various|title=Les Gouvernements du Grand-Duché de Luxembourg depuis 1848|year=2011|publisher=Government of Luxembourg|location=Luxembourg|isbn=978-2-87999-212-9|page=110|url=http://www.gouvernement.lu/publications/gouvernement/gouvernements_depuis_1848/Les_gouvernements_depuis_1848.pdf|format=PDF}}</ref> During the [[First World War]], the 400 men of the [[Luxembourg Army#Corps des Gendarmes et Volontaires|''Corps des Gendarmes et Volontaires'']] had remained in barracks throughout the [[German occupation of Luxembourg in World War I|German occupation]].<ref name=MNHM1>{{cite web|last=Gaul |first=Roland |title=The Luxembourg Army |url=http://www.nat-military-museum.lu/pageshtml/luxembourgarmy.php#4A |publisher=[[National Museum of Military History (Luxembourg)|MNHM]] |accessdate=11 May 2013 |deadurl=unfit |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20060822160910/http://www.nat-military-museum.lu/pageshtml/luxembourgarmy.php#4A |archivedate=August 22, 2006 }}</ref> In March 1939, in a speech to the [[Reichstag (Nazi Germany)|Reichstag]], [[Adolf Hitler]] promised that Luxembourgish sovereignty would not be breached.<ref>{{cite book|last=Office of United States Chief of Counsel for Prosecution of Axis Criminality|title=Nazi Conspiracy and Aggression (1)|year=1946|publisher=United States Government Printing Office|location=|url=http://fundamentalbass.home.mindspring.com/x6860.htm|authorlink=|chapter=9: Launching of Wars of Aggression, section 10 Aggression against Belgium, the Netherlands and Luxembourg}}</ref>
The strength of the military was gradually increased as international tension rose during [[Appeasement]] and after [[United Kingdom|Britain]] and [[French Third Republic|France]]'s declaration of war against [[Nazi Germany|Germany]] in September 1939. By 1940, the Luxembourgish army numbered some 13 officers, 255 armed gendarmes and 425 soldiers.<ref>{{cite book|last=Thomas|first=Nigel|title=Foreign Volunteers of the Allied Forces, 1939–45|year=1991|publisher=Osprey|location=London|isbn=978-1-85532-136-6|page=15}}</ref>
The popular English-language radio station, [[Radio Luxembourg (English)|Radio Luxembourg]] was taken off-air in September 1939, amid fears that it might antagonize the Germans.<ref name=GPW12>{{cite book|last=Fletcher|first=Willard Allen (ed.)|title=Defiant Diplomat: George Platt Waller, American consul in Nazi-occupied Luxembourg 1939–1941|year=2012|publisher=University of Delaware Press|location=Newark|isbn=1-61149-398-6|page=12|author2=Fletcher, Jean Tucker }}</ref> Apart from that, normal life continued in Luxembourg during the [[Phoney War]]; no [[Blackout (wartime)|blackout]] was enforced and regular trains to France and Germany continued.<ref name=GPW13>{{cite book|last=Fletcher|first=Willard Allen (ed.)|title=Defiant Diplomat: George Platt Waller, American consul in Nazi-occupied Luxembourg 1939–1941|year=2012|publisher=University of Delaware Press|location=Newark|isbn=1-61149-398-6|page=13|author2=Fletcher, Jean Tucker }}</ref>
In Spring 1940, work began on a series of roadblocks across Luxembourg's eastern border with Germany. The fortifications, known as the ''[[Schuster Line]]'', were largely made of steel and concrete.{{citation needed|date=September 2013}}
==German Invasion== [[File:SdKfz232-8rad-ardennes-france-1940.png|thumb|right|250px|A [[Schwerer Panzerspähwagen#Sd.Kfz. 232|German armored car]] in the [[Ardennes]] during ''Fall Gelb'', May 1940]] {{main|Invasion of Luxembourg}} On 9 May 1940, after increased troop movements around the German border, the barricades of the Schuster Line were closed.
The German invasion of Luxembourg, part of ''[[Fall Gelb]]'' ("Case Yellow"), began at 04:35 on the same day as the [[Battle of Belgium|attacks on Belgium]] and [[Battle of the Netherlands|the Netherlands]]. An attack by German agents in civilian clothes against the Schuster Line and radio stations was however repulsed.{{citation needed|date=August 2016}} The invading forces encountered little resistance from the Luxembourgish military who were confined in their barracks. By noon, the [[Luxembourg (city)|capital city]] had fallen.
The invasion was accompanied by an exodus of tens of thousands of civilians to France and the surrounding countries to escape the invasion.{{citation needed|date=September 2013}}
At 08:00, several French divisions crossed the frontier from the [[Maginot Line]] and skirmished with the German forces before retreating. The invasion cost 7 Luxembourgish soldiers wounded, with 1 British pilot and 5 French [[Spahi]]s killed in action.<ref>{{cite book|last=Raths|first=Aloyse|title=Unheilvolle Jahre für Luxemburg - Années néfastes pour le Grand-Duché|year=2008|publisher=|location=|page=7}}</ref>
==German Occupation== {{main|German occupation of Luxembourg in World War II}}
===Life under occupation===
The departure of the government left the state functions of Luxembourg in disorder.<ref name=GduGD110-111>{{cite book|last=Various|title=Les Gouvernements du Grand-Duché de Luxembourg depuis 1848|year=2011|publisher=Government of Luxembourg|location=Luxembourg|isbn=978-2-87999-212-9|pages=110–1|url=http://www.gouvernement.lu/publications/gouvernement/gouvernements_depuis_1848/Les_gouvernements_depuis_1848.pdf|format=PDF}}</ref> An administrative council under [[Albert Wehrer]] was formed in Luxembourg to attempt to reach an agreement with the occupiers whereby Luxembourg could continue to preserve some independence while remaining a Nazi protectorate, and called for the return of the Grand Duchess.<ref name=GduGD110-111/> All possibility of compromise was eventually lost when Luxembourg was effectively incorporated into the German ''Gau Koblenz-Trier'' (renamed ''Gau Moselland'' in 1942) and all its own government functions were abolished from July 1940, unlike occupied Belgium and the Netherlands which preserved their state functions under German control.<ref name=GduGD110-111/> From August 1942, Luxembourg was officially made part of Germany.<ref name=USHMM1>{{cite web|title=Luxembourg|url=http://www.ushmm.org/wlc/en/article.php?ModuleId=10005363|publisher=[[United States Holocaust Memorial Museum]]|accessdate=11 May 2013}}</ref>
From August 1940, speaking French was forbidden by proclamation of [[Gustav Simon]] in order to encourage the integration of the territory into Germany, proclaimed by posters carrying the slogan "Your language is German and only German"<ref group=note>"Eure Sprache sei deutsch und nur deutsch"</ref><ref name=GPW102>{{cite book|last=Fletcher|first=Willard Allen (ed.)|title=Defiant Diplomat: George Platt Waller, American consul in Nazi-occupied Luxembourg 1939–1941|year=2012|publisher=University of Delaware Press|location=Newark|isbn=1-61149-398-6|page=102|author2=Fletcher, Jean Tucker }}</ref> This led to a popular revival of the traditional [[Luxembourgish language]], which had not been prohibited, as a form of passive resistance.<ref name=AEL1/>
From August 1942, all male Luxembourgers of draft age were conscripted into the German armed forces.<ref name=HEART1/> Altogether, 12,000 Luxembourgers served in the German military, of whom nearly 3,000 died during the war.<ref name=AEL1>{{cite web|title=World War II|url=http://www.luxembourg.alloexpat.com/luxembourg_information/history_of_luxembourg.php?page=0%2C5|publisher=Allo Expat: Luxembourg|accessdate=11 May 2013}}</ref>
===Collaboration=== {{see also|Volksdeutsche Bewegung|Luxembourgish collaboration with Nazi Germany}} The most significant collaborationist group in the country was the ''[[Volksdeutsche Bewegung]]'' (VdB). Formed by [[Damian Kratzenberg]] shortly after the occupation, the VdB campaigned for the incorporation of Luxembourg into Germany with the slogan "[[Heim ins Reich]]" ("Home to the Reich"). The VdB had 84,000 members at its height, but coercion was widely exercised to encourage enlistment.<ref name=Feldgrau1>{{cite web|title=Luxemburg Collaborationist Forces in During WWII|url=http://www.feldgrau.com/a-lux.html|publisher=Feldgrau|accessdate=11 May 2013}}</ref> All manual workers were forced into the [[German Labour Front]] (DAF) from 1941 and certain age groups of both genders were conscripted into the ''[[Reichsarbeitsdienst]]'' (RAD) to work on military projects.<ref name=Feldgrau1/>
Membership of the Nazi youth movement, the "''Luxemburger Volksjugend''" (LVJ), which had been created with little success in 1936, was encouraged and it later merged into the [[Hitler Youth]].<ref name=Feldgrau1/>
Conscription was introduced in Luxembourg from August 1942 under the same terms as in Germany. 12,000 men were conscripted, of whom 3,000 were killed in action, died of wounds or were posted missing-presumed dead.<ref name=Feldgrau2/> A further 1,500 were wounded.<ref name=Feldgrau2/>
===Resistance=== [[File:Standgericht03SEP42.JPG|thumb|175px|Poster announcing the death sentences of 9 of the 21 Luxembourgers executed for their participation in the [[1942 Luxembourgish general strike|1942 General Strike]].]] {{see also|Luxembourgish Red Lion|Luxembourgish Patriot League}}
Armed resistance to the German occupiers began in winter 1940–41 when a number of small groups were formed across the country.<ref name=HiR:CNA/> Each had differing political objectives and some were directly affiliated to pre-war political parties, social groups (like the Scouts) or groups of students or workers.<ref name=HiR:CNA/> Because of the small size of the pre-war Luxembourgish military, weapons were difficult to come by and so the resistance fighters were rarely armed until much later in the war.<ref name=HiR:CNA/> Nevertheless, the resistance was heavily involved in printing anti-German leaflets and, from 1942, hiding "Réfractaires" (those avoiding German military service) in safe houses, and in some cases providing networks to escort them out of the country safely.<ref name=HiR:CNA/> One Luxembourger, [[Victor Bodson]] (who was also a minister in the Government in Exile), was awarded the title [[Righteous Among the Nations]] by the [[State of Israel]] for helping about 100 Jews escape from Luxembourg during the occupation.<ref>{{cite web|title=Righteous Among the Nations Honored by Yad Vashem: Luxembourg|url=http://www.yadvashem.org/yv/en/righteous/pdf/virtial_wall/luxemburg.pdf|publisher=[[Yad Vashem]]|accessdate=11 May 2013|format=PDF}}</ref>
Information gathered by the Luxembourgish resistance was extremely important. One Luxembourgish resistant, Léon-Henri Roth, informed the allies of the existence of the secret [[Peenemünde Army Research Center]] on the [[Baltic Sea|Baltic coast]], allowing the allies [[Bombing of Peenemünde in World War II|to bomb it from the air]].<ref name=Yapou1>{{cite book|last=Yapou|first=Eliezer|title=Governments in Exile, 1939–1945|year=1998|location=Jerusalem|url=http://governmentsinexile.com/yapouluxembourg.html|chapter=Luxembourg: The Smallest Ally}}</ref>
In Autumn 1944, many resistance organizations merged to form the "Unio'n vun de Fräiheetsorganisatiounen" or [[Unio'n]].<ref name=HiR:CNA/>
In November 1944, a group of 30 Luxembourgish resistance members commanded by [[Victor Abens]] was attacked by [[Waffen SS]] soldiers in [[Vianden Castle|the castle]] at [[Vianden]]. In [[Battle of Vianden|the battle which followed]], 23 Germans were killed by the resistance, who only lost one man killed during the operation although they were forced to withdraw to Allied lines.<ref>{{cite book|last=Raths|first=Aloyse|title=Unheilvolle Jahre für Luxemburg - Années néfastes pour le Grand-Duché|year=2008|publisher=|location=|pages=401–3}}</ref>
====Passive Resistance==== {{see also|1942 Luxembourgish general strike}} Non-violent passive resistance was widespread in Luxembourg during the period. From August 1940, the "Spéngelskrich" (the "War of [[Lapel pin|Pins]]") took place as Luxembourgers wore patriotic pin-badges (depicting the national colours or the Grand duchess), precipitating attacks from the VdB.<ref name=GPW103>{{cite book|last=Fletcher|first=Willard Allen (ed.)|title=Defiant Diplomat: George Platt Waller, American consul in Nazi-occupied Luxembourg 1939–1941|year=2012|publisher=University of Delaware Press|location=Newark|isbn=1-61149-398-6|page=103|author2=Fletcher, Jean Tucker }}</ref>
In October 1941, the German occupiers took a survey of Luxembourgish civilians who were asked to state their nationality, their mother tongue and their racial group, but contrary to German expectations, 95% answered "Luxembourgish" to each question.<ref name=GduGD114>{{cite book|last=Various|title=Les Gouvernements du Grand-Duché de Luxembourg depuis 1848|year=2011|publisher=Government of Luxembourg|location=Luxembourg|isbn=978-2-87999-212-9|page=114|url=http://www.gouvernement.lu/publications/gouvernement/gouvernements_depuis_1848/Les_gouvernements_depuis_1848.pdf|format=PDF}}</ref> The refusal to declare themselves as German citizens led to mass arrests.<ref name=HEART1/>
Conscription was particularly unpopular. On 31 August 1942, shortly after the announcement that conscription would be extended to all men born between 1920 and 1927, a strike began in the northern town of [[Wiltz]].<ref name=HiR:CNA>{{cite web|title=Heim in Reich: La 2e guerre mondiale au Luxembourg - quelques points de repère |url=http://www.cna.public.lu/1_FILM/EnSavoirPlus/dossier_heim_ins_reich/historique/index.html#greve |publisher=Centre National de l'Audiovisuel |accessdate=11 May 2013 |deadurl=unfit |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070610114800/http://www.cna.public.lu/1_FILM/EnSavoirPlus/dossier_heim_ins_reich/historique/index.html#greve |archivedate=June 10, 2007 }}</ref> The strike spread rapidly, paralysing the factories and industries of Luxembourg.<ref>{{cite news|title=Commémoration à l'occasion du 60e anniversaire de la grève générale du 31 août 1942|url=http://www.gouvernement.lu/salle_presse/actualite/2002/08/31greve/index.html|accessdate=11 May 2013|newspaper=Government.lu|date=31 August 2002}}</ref> The strike was quickly repressed and its leaders arrested. 20 were summarily tried before a special tribunal (in German, a "Standgericht") and executed by firing squad at nearby [[Hinzert concentration camp]].<ref name=HiR:CNA/> Nevertheless, protests against conscription continued and 3,500 Luxembourgers would desert the German army after being conscripted.<ref name=Feldgrau2>{{cite web|title=Luxembourg Volunteers in the German Wehrmacht in WWII|url=http://www.feldgrau.com/lux.html|publisher=Feldgrau|accessdate=11 May 2013}}</ref>
===Holocaust=== [[File:Al SynagogueLux Nazidefile.jpg|thumb|right|250px|A Nazi parade by the [[Synagogue]] in [[Luxembourg (city)|Luxembourg]] in 1941. It was destroyed in 1943.]] {{main|The Holocaust in Luxembourg}} Before the war, Luxembourg had a population of about 3500 Jews, many of them newly arrived in the country to escape persecution in Germany.<ref name=USHMM1/> The [[Nuremberg Laws]], which had applied in Germany since 1935, were enforced in Luxembourg from September 1940 and Jews were encouraged to leave the country for [[Vichy France]].<ref name=USHMM1/> Emigration was forbidden in October 1941, but not before nearly 2500 had fled.<ref name=USHMM1/> In practice they were little better off in Vichy France, and many of those who left were later deported and killed. From September 1941, all Jews in Luxembourg were forced to wear the [[Yellow badge|yellow Star of David badge]] to identify them.<ref name=HEART1>{{cite web|title=The Destruction of the Jews of Luxembourg|url=http://www.holocaustresearchproject.org/nazioccupation/luxembourg.html|publisher=Holocaust Education and Archive Research Team|accessdate=11 May 2013}}</ref>
From October 1941, Nazi authorities began to deport the around 800 remaining Jews from Luxembourg to [[Łódź Ghetto]] and the concentration camps at [[Theresienstadt concentration camp|Theresienstadt]] and [[Auschwitz concentration camp|Auschwitz]].<ref name=USHMM1/> Around 700 were deported from the Transit Camp at Fuenfbrunnen in [[Troisvierges|Ulflingen]] in the north of Luxembourg.<ref name=USHMM1/>
Luxembourg was declared "''[[Judenfrei|Judenrein]]''" ("cleansed of Jews") except for those in hiding<ref name="HEART1"/> on 19 October 1941.<ref>{{cite news|title=Commémoration de la Shoah au Luxembourg|url=http://www.gouvernement.lu/salle_presse/actualite/2005/07/03asselborn_shoah/index.html|accessdate=11 May 2013|newspaper=Government.lu|date=3 July 2005}}</ref> Of the original Jewish population of Luxembourg, only 36 are known to have survived the war.<ref name=USHMM1/>
==Free Luxembourgish Forces and the Government in Exile== [[File:Luxembourg Troops Fight With United Nations- Training With the Belgian Army in England, UK, 1943 D16778.jpg|thumb|Soldiers from Luxembourg training in Britain, 1943.]] {{see also|Luxembourgish government-in-exile}} The Government in Exile first fled to [[Paris]], then after the [[Fall of France]], to [[Lisbon]] and then the [[United Kingdom]].<ref name=GduGD110-111/> While the Government established itself in [[Wilton Crescent]] in the [[Belgravia]] area of [[London]], the Grand Duchess and her family moved to Francophone [[Montreal]] in [[Canada]].<ref name=GduGD110-111/> The government in exile was vocal in stressing the Luxembourgish cause in newspapers in allied countries and succeeded in obtaining Luxembourgish language broadcasts to the occupied country on [[British Broadcasting Corporation|BBC radio]].<ref name=GduGD112>{{cite book|last=Various|title=Les Gouvernements du Grand-Duché de Luxembourg depuis 1848|year=2011|publisher=Government of Luxembourg|location=Luxembourg|isbn=978-2-87999-212-9|page=112|url=http://www.gouvernement.lu/publications/gouvernement/gouvernements_depuis_1848/Les_gouvernements_depuis_1848.pdf|format=PDF}}</ref> In 1944, the government in exile signed [[London Customs Convention|a treaty]] with the Belgian and Dutch governments, creating the [[Benelux|Benelux Economic Union]] and also signed into the [[Bretton Woods system]].<ref name=Yapou1/>
Luxembourgish military involvement could play only a "symbolic role" for the allied cause,<ref name=Yapou1/> and numerous Luxembourgers fought in allied armies. From March 1944, Luxembourgish soldiers operated four [[Ordnance QF 25 pounder|25 pounder guns]], christened [[Princess Elisabeth, Duchess of Hohenberg|Elisabeth]], [[Princess Marie Adelaide of Luxembourg|Marie Adelaide]], [[Princess Marie Gabriele of Luxembourg|Marie Gabriele]] and [[Alix, Dowager Princess of Ligne|Alix]] after the Grand duchess' daughters, as part of C Troop, 1st Belgian Field Artillery Battery of the [[1st Belgian Infantry Brigade]], commonly known as the "''Brigade Piron''" after its commander [[Jean-Baptiste Piron]].<ref>{{cite web|title=The 1st Belgian Field Artillery Battery, 1941–1944|url=http://www.be4046.eu/1Aie.htm|publisher=Be4046.eu|accessdate=11 May 2013}}</ref> The Troop numbered some 80 men.<ref name=MNHM1/> The battery landed in Normandy with the ''Brigade Piron'' on 6 August 1944<ref name=MNHM1/> and served in the [[Battle of Normandy]] and was involved in the Liberation of Brussels in September 1944.{{citation needed|date=September 2013}}
[[Jean, Grand Duke of Luxembourg|Prince Jean]], son of the Grand Duchess and future Grand Duke, served in the [[Irish Guards]] from 1942.{{citation needed|date=September 2013}}
==Liberation== [[File:Liberation_of_Wiltz_in_Luxembourg.jpg|thumb|right|250px|The [[Flag of Luxembourg]] flying from the Hospital in [[Wiltz]] shortly after its liberation by the American [[4th Armoured Division (United States)|4th Armoured Division]], 25 December 1944.]] Luxembourg was liberated by Allied forces in September 1944. Allied tanks entered the capital city on 10 September 1944, where the Germans retreated without fighting. The Allied advance triggered the resistance to rise up: at Vianden, members of the Luxembourgish resistance fought a much larger German force at the [[Battle of Vianden|Battle of Vianden Castle]]. In mid December, the Germans launched the "[[Ardennes Offensive]]" in Luxembourg and the Belgian Ardennes. Though the city of Luxembourg remained in Allied hands throughout, much of the north of the country was lost to German forces and had to be liberated again.{{citation needed|date=September 2013}}
[[Gustav Simon]], the Nazi ''Gauleiter'' responsible for Moselland and Luxembourg, fled but was captured and imprisoned by the British Army. He committed suicide in an Allied prison. In Luxembourg too, collaborators were imprisoned and tried. [[Damian Kratzenberg]], founder and leader of VdB, was one of those executed for his role.{{citation needed|date=September 2013}}
Two German [[V-3 cannon]] with a range of {{convert|40|km|mi|abbr=on}} were used to bombard the city of Luxembourg from December 1944 until February 1945.<ref>{{cite web|title=V-3: The High Pressure Pump Gun|url=http://www.battlefieldsww2.com/V3_The_High_Pressure_Pump_Gun.html|publisher=Battlefieldsww2.com|accessdate=11 May 2013}}</ref>
==Battle of the Bulge== {{main|Battle of the Bulge}} Most of Luxembourg was rapidly liberated in September 1944 when the front line stabilized behind the [[Our River|Our]] and [[Sauer River]]s along the Luxembourg-German frontier. Following the campaign in Brittany, the U.S. VIII Corps occupied the sector of the front line in Luxembourg. On December 16, 1944, elements of the U.S. 28th and 4th Infantry Divisions, as well as a [[combat command]] of the 9th Armored Division were defending the line of the Our and Sauer Rivers when the [[Battle of the Bulge|German offensive]] started.{{citation needed|date=September 2013}}
[[File:Bundesarchiv Bild 183-1985-0104-501, Ardennenoffensive, Grenadiere in Luxemburg.jpg|thumb|left|German ''[[Volksgrenadier]]'' in Luxembourg, December 1944.]] The initial defensive efforts of the U.S. troops hinged upon holding towns near the international frontier. As a result, the towns of Clervaux, Marnach, Holzthum, Consthum, Weiler, and Wahlhausen<ref name=Lbda1>{{cite web|title=La bataille des Ardennes|url=http://www.secondeguerremondiale.public.lu/fr/dossiers-thematiques/batailledesardennes/index.html|publisher=Secondeguerremondiale.public.lu|accessdate=28 June 2013}}</ref> were used as strongholds by the Americans and attacked by the Germans, who wanted to achieve control of the road networks in northern Luxembourg in order for their forces to move westward. After the Americans in northern Luxembourg were forced to retreat by the German attacks, the area experienced a second passage of the front line during January–February 1945, this time moving generally eastward as the U.S. Third Army attacked into the southern flank of the German penetration (the "Bulge"). [[Vianden]] was the final community in Luxembourg to be liberated on 12 February 1945.<ref name=Lbda1/>
Because of the determination of both sides to prevail on the battlefield, the combat in Luxembourg was bitter and correspondingly hard on the civilian population. Over 2,100 homes in Luxembourg were destroyed in the fighting and more than 1,400 others seriously damaged. It is also estimated that some 500 Luxembourgish non-combatants lost their lives during the Battle of the Bulge.<ref>{{cite book|last=Schrijvers|first=Peter|title=The Unknown Dead: Civilians in the Battle of the Bulge|year=2005|publisher=University Press of Kentucky|location=|page=361|isbn=0-8131-2352-6}}</ref> Besides the dead, over 45,000 Luxembourgers became refugees during the battle.{{citation needed|date=September 2013}}
==Aftermath== {{see also|Luxembourg annexation plans after the Second World War}}
The experience of invasion and occupation during the war led to a shift in Luxembourg's stance on neutrality.<ref>{{cite web|title=Luxemburg nach dem Ende des Zweiten Weltkriegs|url=http://histoprim.cte.lu/lehrer/wk17.html|publisher=HIistoprim Online|accessdate=8 June 2013}}</ref> Luxembourg signed the [[Treaty of Brussels]] with other western European powers on 17 March 1948 as part of the initial European postwar security cooperation and in a move that foreshadowed Luxembourg's membership in [[NATO]]. Luxembourg also began greater military co-operation with Belgium after the war, training soldiers together and even sending [[Belgian United Nations Command|a joint contingent]] to fight in the [[Korean War]] in 1950.{{citation needed|date=September 2013}}
Following the war, Luxembourgish troops took part in the occupation of [[West Germany]], contributing troops that were part of the force in the [[Allied Occupation Zones in Germany|French Zone]], beginning in late 1945. Luxembourgish forces functioned under overall French command within the zone and were responsible for the areas of [[Bitburg]] and [[Eifel]] and parts of [[Saarburg]]. They were withdrawn from Saarburg in 1948, and from Bitburg-Eifel in July 1955.{{citation needed|date=September 2013}}
